ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We often had to do asynchronous group projects towards the beginning of the semester and we had independent TA meetings once a week.
Virtual career talks, weekly discussion section with teaching fellow
Zoom classes, virtual TA language sessions
We would have live virtual lectures, regular breakout rooms for discussion, and group project work.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really developed my writing skills through practice, and learned many interesting expressions and idioms that brought me closer to fluency. Above that, I learned and grew to appreciate many facets of Korean culture through looking at various forms of media and helpful discussions. Weekly participation in the discussion section also significantly improved my improvisational speaking skills.
Increase skills in writing, speaking Korean
Reading Korean poems, stories, and getting some into politics. Constantly worked on speaking and writing ability through class discussions and assignments.

I learned how to speak Korean at a higher level. By using the drama Misaeng, I was able to improve my understanding of Korean business politics and also learn more Korean business words. This class also taught me a lot about traditional Korean tales, and these tales allowed me to have a greater understanding of Korean values.

This course strengthened my Korean reading, writing, listening, and speaking skills. As the curriculum incorporated a variety of materials, I developed my reading and comprehension skills across a variety of written styles.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: By far the greatest strength is the professor who is very caring and understanding of every student. Despite the virtual barrier, the class felt like a community and the learning environment was very relaxed, allowing for everyone to improve at their own pace. There are very few weaknesses, except that some assignments may feel like busy work. I could benefit from an occasional vocabulary quiz, since I found it difficult to quickly incorporate new vocabulary into my vernacular.

strengths: fun class, professor is literally the best, fun assignments
weakness: some assignments take way too much time

Definitely the most engaging professor I've had so far. She's incredibly supportive and caring, and the TF discussion section was so much fun. Even if you're terrified of being cold-called like me, the classroom environment was definitely so good that I eventually didn't mind at all. 
I didn't mind the homework load too much, but sometimes it got a little tedious. The positives definitely outweigh the negatives in this class.

Strengths:
This course had different types of engagement every day which was critical to learning more and diverse vocabulary. I was able to speak with my professor and fellow students on a range of topics while also learning at the same time. I did really enjoy breakout rooms and group work, especially during the pandemic. It allowed me to get closer to some of my classmates. 

Weaknesses: 
I would have loved to have more grammatical work just to keep refreshing on different structures.

While I found the assignments challenging enough to build my proficiency, I also felt that they were manageable in terms of workload. I also appreciated the pacing of the course leading up to the final assignment, as the course was structured so that students built up to the research assignment with weekly check-ins, which also helped the workload feel distributed over the course of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lee ssn is very understanding about any circumstances that arise and is adaptable. The course changed quite a bit over the semester as she took in feedback from the students and made the class better suited to where we were all at mentally and physically.

Overall I thought the course made the most of the virtual format - discussion sections still served its purpose of fostering conversations and classes were run smoothly thanks to screen sharing capabilities of Zoom. Every assignment and lesson plan was properly prepared for virtual instruction. I can't particularly think of aspects of the course that need to be improved with respect to virtual learning.
Class participation and engagement was high
I think Professor Lee-Smith handled it excellently.

I believe that the breakout rooms and group work succeeded to an extent. It was difficult to find time to meet, but that time was spent making new connections. I will say that the time went quickly on zoom, and I believe that we could have spent more time engaging in conversation on some days. I also believe the access to resources on Canvas was critical and really helpful when reviewing work.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. The course is genuinely fun and has a relaxed, welcoming atmosphere but you will still get a lot out of it, in terms of improving your writing and speaking skills and your understanding of Korean culture. The professor alone makes this course worth your time. The workload is very manageable and doesn't take up a large portion of your week.
Yes! Definitely take this class with Lee teacher. You'll learn a lot

YES
The class environment is supportive and the prof does so much to make sure everyone is engaged. She's very friendly and so considerate.

I would absolutely recommend this class to another student. Even if you are not a heritage speaker, this class is wonderful to take. This class can teach you much more about Korean culture and interpersonal and intrapersonal cultural dynamics.
Yes!
I would recommend this course to another student.

        Adv Korean for Adv Learners
